Thank you, Professor!
Not a math trained person: Anyone care to explain how does (cos x + cos^2 x + sin^2 x) becomes (1 + cos x) @ 7:16? Any material I can look up to?

No you can’t, because the entirety of cos2x + sin2x is being divided by cos2x.  Kinda like if you did (1 + 3) / 3 you can’t just cancel the three’s. If you separate everything you could get 1/3 + 3/3 so if you did a similar thing with this example problem you could get cos2x / cos2x + sin2x / cos2x which simplifies to 1 + sin2x / cos2x which is the same as 1 + tan2x. And according to the pythagorean identities 1 + tan2x = sec2x which is the exact same answer he has.
Thanks! I wonder if I'm going to need to memorise all these identities. @ddevil768

This video doesn't  "prove" a damn thing.  All it does is visually illustrate. Typical of "Prof Dave" he vastly oversimplifies and therefore ultimately misleads.

@davidmajor1508  He's not claiming to prove anything in this video, nor is he giving an oversimplification that would give misleading ideas.  He's just giving idea behind how you can intuitively understand the derivative cycle of sine and cosine, and how you can recall it quickly, if you ever forget.   Most people who will use practical applications of trigonometric derivatives don't need to know the formal the proof through the squeeze theorem from first principles, but knowing this illustration can help you recreate what you really would need to know.
@Carl Hansen   The person I responded to DID indeed mention "proof". READ.
@Carl Hansen  How does this  magically help one "intuitively" understand?

@Carl Hansen   LOL If you understand what derivatives mean in terms of slopes, you DON'T need this "illustration", and if you DON'T know or have forgotten derivatives, this "illustration" really won't help you remember or understand.   See? Indeed an oversimplification on your part.
@Carl Hansen    What part of the phrase "proving trig derivatives visually" do you have problems understanding? Or is it context you have issues with? Both, maybe?

@davidmajor1508  Put it this way.  Suppose you remember that sine and cosine are each others' derivatives with a cycle of signs, but you don't remember when the sign is plus, or when the sign is minus.  Suppose you wanted to know cosine's derivative.    You start by sketching cosine's graph at each quarter turn position within the cycle.  You know it starts at 1, and proceeds to equal zero at a quarter turn, equals -1 after a half turn, then zero at the 3rd quarter, then it returns to 1 after a full cycle.  You then look at the zero crossings at each quarter turn.  It is falling at the first quarter, and rising at the third quarter.  Since it is falling at the first quarter, this means we need its derivative to be negative at this point.  Sine is positive at the first quarter, so this means cosine's derivative would be -sin(x).
@Carl Hansen   Ah-huh. This only works if you know how derivatives correspond to slopes (and values at a point).
@carultch    AS I ALREADY SAID.  LOL

@davidmajor1508  You seem to have an all-or-nothing attitude about what you consider a valid explanation of math.  You seem to think that if it isn't a rigorous proof without holes, that it is useless to even learn.
@Carl Hansen   Strawman.  You clearly don't understand what I'm say, or are purposefully misconstruing it.

@davidmajor1508  I'm not purposely misconstruing anything.  You seem to be arguing that Dave's presentation of a simple way to understand basic trigonometric derivatives is useless, just because it isn't a formal proof.  That's what I'm hearing from you.
@Carl Hansen   Then you don't understand what I'm saying about derivatives.
@davidmajor1508  Well what are you saying about derivatives, then?  Because you clearly aren't saying what you think you are saying.

@Carl Hansen   LOL Clearly, you don't understand what I'm saying about derivatives and slopes (corresponding tangent lines and values at point) in terms of being able to grasp this illustration or use it as you described.  Really, if you don't grasp that one has to understand how derivatives correspond to slopes-- tangent lines and values at a point -- then you clearly don't understand derivatives or what you're talking about.

@davidmajor1508  You really do have an all-or-nothing attitude about this.  I've known what a derivative is for over half my life, so please stop insisting that I don't know what I'm talking about, unless you can point to a specific example where I've said something incorrect about derivatives.  You seem to think that just because someone forgot the cycle of signs in the derivative cycle of sine and cosine, that I'm implying that they also forgot what a derivative is, in general.  Far from it.  I'm saying that this illustration of Dave's is useful for someone who already is proficient in the basics of what a derivative is.  Someone who simply needs to know how to recall that the derivatives of sine and cosine follow a cycle of +C, -S, -C, +S, and simply forgot that cycle.   It also works as a basic introduction, even if it isn't a formal proof.
@carultch   You don't grasp that if you don't understand derivatives, this "illustration" is meaningless.

@carultch   You assert: "You really do have an all-or-nothing attitude about this."  Show me the quote. Be explicit about "this". What do you mean by "this"? What is "this" that  I have am "all or nothing" attitude about? Quote me.

@carultch   You assert: "I've known what a derivative is for over half my life, so please stop insisting that I don't know what I'm talking about, unless you can point to a specific example where I've said something incorrect about derivatives."  If you think this "illustration" can by fully comprehended without understanding how derivatives are related to slope (tangent line and value at a point), then, yes, you do NOT know that you're talking about.

Far from it.'  LOL Really? Where did I suggest that is what you are implying? Quote me.

@Carl Hansen   In fact, having both taught mathematics and worked with engineers, I can verify for a fact that people can remember little factoids like sine and cosine being derivatives of one another while losing or forgetting their overall understanding of the CONCEPT of a derivative, including what derivatives tell you about slopes (tangent lines and values at a point.) @Carl Hansen   Besides, you DID accuse: You explicitly said "You really do have am all-or-nothing attitude about this." And if it were the case that they forgot what a derivative is in general, then this trick to recalling the cycle of derivatives won't work for them.  Sure someone could forget the entire meaning of a derivative, but explaining what a derivative is in general, isn't the topic of this video.  That's an earlier video in this playlist.

@davidmajor1508  I said that, because you keep getting bent out of shape about the way Dave presented this topic, and I can't understand why.  You accused Dave of oversimplifying and misleading.  I don't see any point in his video where he misled anyone in his audience.  I gave a reason why his lesson would be useful, even if it is oversimplified. And it would really only be of interest to someone who knew in advance that they wanted to see the complete proof.  Nor did he explain what a derivative is in general, since that's a topic in an earlier video.
@carultch   No, I'm not expanding anything. You are making an unfounded assumption based based on them knowing a factoid, as I already explained.

@Carl Hansen   The fact remains that you ACCUSED, then when I asked you for the quote that demonstrate that accusation you admitted you had none, just "a feeling".  When I pointed out that means you have no evidence and are just accusing baselessly based on you're feelings, you DENIED you had ever accused, but just said "it seems".  NOW that I showed you your own words where it's undeniable that you actually DID accuse, you CHANGE your story once again.   LOL

@Carl Hansen    Now that I've established your shifting narrative-- which should be enough to establish your BAD FAITH, buy I'll ignore that and give you a chance to redeem yourself:  Where do "I keep getting bent out of shape about this"? What is "this"? Be explicit, a vagueness is the playground of liars and charlatans.  "Keep getting betting out of shape" implied more than once. Show me the quotes where I "keep getting". Use logic to demonstrate that it's me "getting bent out of shape".
@davidmajor1508  It's my hypothetical example, I can define it anyway I want.  And it's not just hypothetical, I've used this technique myself to recall it.

@Carl Hansen   Professor Dave DID oversimplify by NOT EXPLICITLY explaining that his graphical approach is MERELY and ONLY a graphical presentation that is NO way a proof, including NOT even a visual proof. A rigorous thinking mathematician KNOWS to make such things EXPLICIT, especially to beginning students. He also compounded this oversimplification by claiming it is "learning how to take the derivative of", and I'll expound on that later.    And, someone, the OP of this thread, DID end up thinking it was a "proving derivatives visually", precisely because of the of the oversimplification and failures I just discussed, which, yes, means he ultimately mislead, as I pointed out.  As for "learning how  to take a the derivative of"...  Learning what a derivative equals is NOT the same thing as "learning how to take the derivative of".   "Learning how to take the derivative of" signals a RIGOROUS approach that uses the definition of the derivative that is applied to the left hand side to derive the right hand side.   A graphical presentation and stating what a derivative is equal to is NOT learning "how to take the derivative", it is merely learning what the derivative is equal to. To say his presentation is "leaning how to take the derivative" is an oversimplification and misleading.  So, he did indeed oversimplify and mislead, for the reasons I've discussed and presented.  There is nothing wrong with what he did per se as long as what is really going on - that it's geometric presentation using tangent lines-- is explicitly stated.  Edit: In mathematics the phrase "take the derivative of" is simply a way to indicate what the derivative is equal to, it does not mean one knows "how" to take the derivative, which does indeed require using the definition of a derivative.

@Carl Hansen  LOL You didn't really define it, though, even implicitly.  Your example ONLY works if one understands what a derivative is, and there is no explicit or  implicit condition in your hypothetical that makes that clear.
